WASHINGTON A sheriff's department in North Dakota is investigating possible charges against the U.S. Green Party presidential candidate
column2: Jill Stein
column3: for damaging equipment during protests on Tuesday over construction of an oil pipeline.Stein was part of a group protesting the Dakota Access pipeline and spray-painted construction equipment
column4: the Morton County Sheriff's Department said. Stein does not dispute the account.Protesters
column5: who say the project will damage burial sites considered sacred to a nearby Native American tribe and pollute the area's drinking water
column6: also attached themselves to bulldozers and broke a fence
column8: a 66-year-old doctor and environmental activist from Massachusetts
column9: said in a statement that she had spray-painted the words ""I approve this message"" onto a bulldozer
column10: a nod to the phrase American politicians append to their advertisements to comply with transparency laws. No arrests were made
column12: and the investigation was continuing. The department also posted a picture on its Facebook page that showed Stein spraying the bulldozer

column1: The $3.7 billion
column3: 100-mile (1
column4: 800-km) pipeline project would be the first to move crude oil from the Bakken shale
column5: a vast oil formation in North Dakota
column6: to refineries on the U.S. Gulf Coast. Energy Transfer Partners is leading a group of firms to build it. The project sparked violent clashes during the weekend between tribe members and other protesters and security officers near the construction site
column7: and the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe is seeking a court order to block construction.The Green Party opposes continued investment in oil extraction because of its link to climate change.

column1: I hope the North Dakota authorities press charges against the real vandalism taking place at the Standing Rock Sioux reservation: the bulldozing of sacred burial sites and the unleashing of vicious attack dogs
column2: Stein said in her statement. She said that pipeline security officials had used dogs and pepper spray on protesters over the weekend. A spokeswoman for Energy Transfer Partners did not respond to a request for comment.

column1: A Reuters-Ipsos poll in late August showed Stein the first choice of 2 percent of voters
column2: trailing Democrat Hillary Clinton
column3: Republican Donald Trump and Libertarian Gary Johnson. The U.S. presidential election will be held on Nov. 8.Stein was arrested for trespassing in Texas during her 2012 presidential campaign when she tried to take supplies to protesters opposed to the Keystone XL pipeline. column1: Our review of this matter will be robust

2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-saudi-security-idUSKCN11D2JQ	Obama administration arms sales offers to Saudi top $115 billion: report	"
By Yara Bayoumy
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama's administration has offered Saudi Arabia more than $115 billion in weapons
column2: other military equipment and training
column3: the most of any U.S. administration in the 71-year U.S.-Saudi alliance
column4: a report seen by Reuters has found. The report
column5: authored by William Hartung of the U.S.-based Center for International Policy
column6: said the offers were made in 42 separate deals
column7: and the majority of the equipment has yet to be delivered. Hartung told Reuters the report would be made available publicly on Sept. 8. The report said U.S. arms offers to Saudi Arabia since Obama took office in January 2009 have included everything from small arms and ammunition to tanks
column11: and warships. Washington also provides maintenance and training to Saudi security forces.The Center's report is based on data from the Defense Security Cooperation Agency
column12: a Department of Defense body that provides figures on arms sales offers and Foreign Military Sales agreements. Most of the offers
column14: become formal agreements though some are abandoned or amended. The report did not disclose how many of the offers to Saudi Arabia were agreed. Washington's arms sales to Riyadh recently have come under fire from rights groups and some members of Congress are disturbed by the rising number of civilian casualties in the war in Yemen
column15: where a coalition led by Saudi Arabia is fighting Iran-allied Houthi rebels.The conflict has killed at least 10
column16: 000 people.  Last month the United Nations human rights office said that 3
column17: 799 civilians have died in the conflict
column18: with coalition air strikes responsible for an estimated 60 percent of the deaths.

column1: The coalition says it does not target civilians and accuses the Houthis of placing military targets in civilian areas. The coalition has created a body to investigate civilian casualties.The outcry over those casualties has led some members of Congress to push for restrictions on arms transfers
column2: and amid the growing outcry
column3: the Pentagon cautioned that its support for Saudi Arabia in its Yemen campaign was not ""a blank check"".The Control Arms coalition
column4: a group that campaigns for stricter arms sales controls
column5: said last month that Britain
column6: France and the United States were flouting the 2014 Arms Trade treaty
column7: which bans exports of conventional weapons that fuel human rights violations or war crimes.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: the Obama administration last month approved a potential $1.15 billion arms package for Saudi Arabia.Hartung said the level of U.S. arms sales to Riyadh should give it leverage to pressure Saudi Arabia.""It's time for the Obama administration to use the best leverage it has - Saudi Arabia's dependence on U.S. weapons and support - to wage the war in Yemen in the first place
column3: Hartung told Reuters.

column1: Pulling back the current offer of battle tanks or freezing some of the tens of billions in weapons and services in the pipeline would send a strong signal to the Saudi leadership that they need stop their indiscriminate bombing campaign and take real steps to prevent civilian casualties.""Washington has been at pains to prove to Saudi Arabia and other Gulf allies that it remains committed to their defense against Iran in the wake of a multinational deal last year to restrict the Iranian nuclear program. Sunni Muslim Gulf states accuse Shi'ite Iran of fomenting instability in the region
column2: which the Islamic Republic denies.""The more recent deals that have involved resupplying Saudi Arabia with ammunition
column3: bombs
column4: and tanks to replace weaponry used up or damaged in the war in Yemen are no doubt driven in part by the effort to 'reassure' the Saudis that the U.S. will not tilt towards Iran in the wake of the nuclear deal
column5: Hartung said.     (Writing by Yara Bayoumy; Editing by John Walcott and Diane Craft)"	['Obama']	[]

7	7	http://reuters.com/article/uk-new-jersey-bridgegate-idUSKCN11D1YT	'Bridgegate' names can remain secret: U.S. appeals court	"
By Jonathan Stempel and Joseph Ax
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK A federal appeals court on Wednesday rejected an effort by news media to force prosecutors in the George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal known as ""Bridgegate"" to disclose the names of unindicted co-conspirators.Reversing a lower court ruling
column2: the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia found no right of public access under the U.S. Constitution's First Amendment or the common law to a list of people implicated but not criminally charged.The 3-0 decision came one day before jury selection was scheduled to begin in the trial of two former allies of New Jersey Governor Chris Christie who are accused of arranging the September 2013 shutdown of bridge access lanes in Fort Lee
column3: New Jersey
column4: causing several days of gridlock.""Public access to judicial documents and court proceedings is a respected tradition and important legal principle
column5: but it has bounds
column6: Circuit Judge Kent Jordan wrote.While it may make sense to release the names at trial

column1: Prosecutors accused William Baroni
column2: a former deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
column3: and Bridget Anne Kelly
column4: a former Christie deputy chief of staff
column5: of closing lanes to punish Fort Lee's Democratic mayor
column7: for not endorsing the successful re-election of Christie
column8: a Republican.Disclosing the list could have shown whether other Christie allies sought political payback by snarling traffic.Another former Port Authority official
column10: is cooperating with prosecutors after pleading guilty.

column1: Christie has denied involvement
column2: but the scandal helped erode his once-high approval ratings. He ran unsuccessfully this year for the White House. His office had no immediate comment.U.S. District Judge Susan Wigenton in Newark had in May ordered disclosing the names of unindicted co-conspirators
column3: but a ""John Doe"" on the list appealed
column4: fearing reputational harm.Bruce Rosen
column5: a lawyer for media companies including ABC
column6: the Associated Press and the New York Times
column7: in an email said his clients are disappointed
column8: and no decision on an appeal has been made.

column1: Doe's lawyer
column2: Jenny Kramer
column3: in an email said she was gratified that the appeals court ""prevented disclosure of highly prejudicial material.""A spokesman for U.S. Attorney Paul Fishman in New Jersey
column4: who supported Doe
column5: declined to comment.Baroni and Kelly have pleaded not guilty to wire fraud
column6: civil rights deprivation and conspiracy charges
column7: and received the list of names to help prepare for trial. Their lawyers did not immediately respond to requests for comment. (Reporting by Joseph Ax and Jonathan Stempel; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama and Matthew Lewis)"	['Paul'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-cuba-usa-flights-congress-idUSKCN11D21O	U.S. lawmakers want moratorium on commercial flights to Cuba	"

WASHINGTON Two leading critics of President Barack Obama's moves toward normal relations with Cuba introduced legislation on Wednesday seeking to temporarily halt commercial flights between the United States and the island because of security concerns.Republican Senator Marco Rubio and Democratic Senator Robert Menendez
column2: both Cuban-American opponents of Obama's Cuba policy
column3: introduced the Cuban Airport Security Act. The measure would stop commercial flights until after a study of security measures and equipment at airports in Cuba.The U.S. government has granted several U.S. airlines permission to begin scheduled flights to Cuba
column4: opening another chapter in the Obama administration's efforts to improve ties and increase trade and travel with the former Cold War foe.A JetBlue Airways Corp passenger jet flew to Santa Clara
column5: Cuba
column8: on Aug. 31. It was the first scheduled commercial passenger flight from the United States to Cuba in more than half a century.

column1: Commercial flights to the capital
column2: Havana
column3: are expected to begin later this year.Obama's Cuba policy sharply divides the U.S. Congress.  Opponents
column4: mostly Republicans but also a few Democrats
column5: say he is moving too quickly to ease restrictions on travel and trade
column6: given continuing human rights violations by its Communist government.

column1: Backers say it is time to try another tactic in dealing with Havana after more than half a century with no change under the previous policy.

A version of the bill was introduced in the House of Representatives in July. There has been no announcement of when the measure might come up for a vote. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Bill Trott)"	['Rubio'

column1: By Arshad Mohammed and Jeff Mason

(Note: Paragraphs 1 and 9 contain strong language that might offend some readers)By Arshad Mohammed and Jeff MasonWASHINGTON/TAMPA The U.S. State Department and Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton on Tuesday stressed the need for ties with the Philippines to be based on mutual respect
column2: after Manila's new leader raised worries about the future of the key alliance by calling President Barack Obama a ""son of a bitch.""Despite U.S. dismay over Duterte's remarks
column3: current and former U.S. officials played down the impact
column4: saying they did not expect any serious damage to ties at a time of high tensions over China's extensive territorial claims in Asia.The State Department said a planned first meeting between Obama and his counterpart Rodrigo Duterte on the sidelines of a regional summit in Laos on Tuesday was canceled because the tone of the Philippine leader's rhetoric raised questions about the chances of productive talks.""Words matter
column5: and we want to see an atmosphere that is cordial and open to strong cooperation
column6: State Department spokesman Mark Toner told a regular news briefing in Washington.Clinton
column7: who as secretary of state was an architect of Obama's policy of emphasizing the importance of the Asia Pacific to U.S. interests in the face of a rising China
column8: said Obama was right to cancel the meeting.""When the president of the Philippines insulted our president
column9: it was appropriate in a very low-key way to say: sorry
column11: she told reporters on her campaign plane.""We have a lot of ties between the United States and the Philippines. And I think it's very important that we have a relationship
column12: but there has to be a certain level of respect that is expected on both sides
column13: Clinton said.Duterte made the remark about Obama while explaining that he would not be lectured over extrajudicial killings in the war against drugs he has launched since taking over two months ago and which has killed about 2

column1: He has previously called the pope a ""son of a whore"" and the U.S. ambassador a ""gay son of whore.""The Philippines voiced regret for Duterte's comments after Obama canceled a formal bilateral meeting. The White House then said Obama might speak with Duterte informally.""FEELING HIS WAY""

Duterte's volatile nature threatens to complicate Washington's ties with its closest ally in Southeast Asia as it tries to forge a united front in the region in response to China's extensive claims in the strategic South China Sea.
The Philippines has been central in this effort due to an international court case it brought and won against Beijing. In March
column2: the United States and the Philippines agreed on five locations for U.S. military facilities in the country under a new security deal. The deal grants Washington increased military presence in its former colony through rotation of ships and planes for humanitarian and maritime security operations. Asked about Duterte's comments
column3: U.S. Secretary of Defense Ash Carter said the defense relationship with the Philippines was a ""strong"" and ""longstanding"" one.Speaking to reporters
column4: Carter also described the Philippines' new defense minister
column5: Delfin Lorenzana
column6: as someone who was ""very knowledgeable about all the things that we do together.""An official of the U.S. State Department said ""government to government"" relations with Manila remained strong.

column1: The areas that we believe we have robust
column2: strong cooperation with them
column3: we are not going to just simply throw that aside.""The official noted that Duterte was new to national leadership having served as a city mayor.""He is maybe feeling his way into the new job
column4: the official said.Former U.S. officials said China would be pleased by the U.S.-Philippines friction.    ""Time will tell whether President Duterte steps back from this episode and realizes he needs to recalibrate his choice of words in engaging U.S. leaders
column5: said Amy Searight
column6: a former senior Pentagon official now at Washington's Center for Strategic and International Studies think tank.Evan Medeiros
column7: Obama's former top Asia adviser and now a senior analyst at the Eurasia Group
column8: saw the row as a ""speed bump
column9: not a road block"" in U.S.-Philippines ties.    ""It's unfortunate
column10: but doesn't fundamentally derail the relationship
column11: he said. (Additional reporting by David Brunnstrom
column12: Matt Spetalnick and Patricia Zengerle in Washington and Phil Stewart in London; Editing by Stuart Grudgings.)"	['Obama'
